content:
Fixing tag: "Arithmetics" -> "Arithmetic".

By the way, this is the only puzzle with the tag "Check-Digit".

I changed the first exemple in the statement:
It was written that the sum "0×10 + 3×9 + 0×8 + 6×7 + 4×6 + 0×5 + 6×4 + 1×3 + 5×2" was equal to 270 instead of 130.
It changes nothing to the final result but that was very confusing for the first exemple...
A little more touch about range of valid characters. Moved it to the end of the statement.
java_coffee_cup, add more tests into test cases, it happens too often that people are struggling with 100% in your test cases and 50%/75% in validators

Clarified in the constraints that the ISBNs contain digits and X only.

Hmmm, the statement states that the task is to use the CHECK DIGITS to validate only. In the "Longer" validator, one ISBN contains "X" in the middle... Is that out of scope?

As discussed subthread, I moved back to puzzle (Easy) and approved.

I edited the ISBN-10 example to use actual multiplication marks as in the ISBM-13 one, because starting a computation with string "0x" reads way too much like hexadecimal literals to my recovering C programmer's mind.

I'd personally not reject a CoC for being too hard as I'm not aware enough of the current level of affairs. But after implementing it on my own, I'd personally dislike it as a clash, for the following reasons:

* a lot of implementation minutiae that makes it look factorable between 10 and 13, but not enough to be useful, yet the text is already long and a clash (IMHO) ought to be solvable in time on the first try.

* OTOH replayability is bad, coding enjoyment-wise.

In other words, too much of a copy-paste fodder clash puzzle.
What if no ISBN is invalid?

Upvoted, because i had to implement something like this for a library software!
You could add strings like "978-3570103197" with - or spaces, because you find ISBN numbers on amazon like this
Updated the output requirement - now it is not necessary to output a hundred lines of true/false. Only need a few lines to indicate the invalid entries found.

The code was updated and were the test-cases too. I also put in test cases having the last digit as 0.
Thanks your feedback

Your answers are wrong for all of the valid ISBNs that end in '0'.
Your code "11 - (sum % 11)"  makes the check digit 11 instead of 0.

Thanks your feedback, Ace.
Not sure is it appropriate to write instructions as pseudo code. No problem with me to rewrite it as wanted by the Community.
For the '%' operator, I know at least Pascal is not using it. Pascal writes it as 'mod'. Not sure about some other languages I do not know. So I chose to describe it by layman English.
And again, I am open to making changes. Thanks.

Puzzles teaching about concepts found around us are always interesting and pleasant to work with. The only issue I have with this one is the explanation formatting needs a little work. Below is an example that would make it clearer to me since it omits excess words and details about Modulus, but maybe not everyone else.
ISBN-10 (Modulus 11)
     ABCDEFGHIJ
     Sum (Bold) = Ax10 + Bx9 + Cx8 + Dx7 + ... + Ix2 + Jx1
     Sum % 11 = 0, making it valid (Bold)
ISBN-13 (Modulus 10)
     ...
     ...
     Sum % 10 = 0, making it valid (Bold) - I'm not sure if using % is appropriate for all languages, but it's clear to me
It's not that hard for a community puzzle, I would see this more as a CoC than a puzzle, but it's interesting to see an exercice about check sum different than "Luhn checksum" :D
Yes, I think this can be reclassified as a CoC.
I don't understand why some of the ISBNs ending with 0 are considered invalid, e.g. 9781482587630 in validator 3 and 9780133661750 in validator 4.
Good point. Not intended to make it  more complicated than necessary. Will clarify it
For now, I'll just add that "X" may appear in any position in the ISBNs. If that is not sufficient, either rewrite the task or remove that ISBN.

Further formatted the text.

Removed the notion of invalid check digit in the ISBN-13 example to avoid confusion.

Standardised the calculation steps in both systems.

Moved the task to near the bottom of the statement.

Added 9780306406157 to the example test case.

Also added 1X2 to the example test case... hopefully inspiring one to know that they have to check for valid length and valid position of X as well if they don't read the puzzle statement properly.
Still hoping that we don't really need to show a test case of an ISBN of 11/12/>13 digits though, as subtle hints have been given. :D

Added in the Example test case: 97803X6406157 (ISBN-13). Now the only "unseen" case is 812X335961 (ISBN-10) in Longer validator.

Also modified your code as it wasn't able to mark 97803X6406157 as invalid.
Never mind. Edited the task and define more about a valid ISBN.

'X' is only used in ISBN-10 and is only used for a check digit. The body of the ISBN should contain only numbers.
(Many publishers add space and dash to separate the digits for easy reading but these are redundant and not included in this puzzle.) 
Having a non-digit (e.g. alphabet) within the body is by definition invalid. The validator should return exception while parsing the data body.
OK
Thank you finding it out. There was a bug no one noticed for a long time. Now fixed.
Thanks. Edited the input, output and constraints sections, and names of some test cases and validators, and approved.
Very nice!
Fine to make it a CoC, Let us know if you feel it could be very impossible to finish the task in time.

I disagree, I actually like this kind of puzzle as a teaching puzzle so it matches the difficulty of a CoC but definitely have a place in the easy puzzles of the community.
Maybe consider submitting this twice or for both.

I really like those instructional puzzles

My comment is 11 months old, there wasn't the difficulty implemented in CP, but yeah, as a teaching exercise it's very interesting ; to submit it twice is a smart way of solving this problem ^^
But it means it could be the case with a lot of CoC / easy puzzle, doesn't ?

I'm fine both ways. Let me clarify my last comment; I mean this contribution can be reclassified as a clash of code, or it can remain as a community puzzle.

The current CoC system is supposedly a secret system (https://forum.codingame.com/t/faq-really-frequently-asked-questions/409/52). Having the same contribution in both CoC and community puzzle categories would break that system (or make the system more broken than it already is).

I don't clash anymore, but I think this puzzle in general has a *lot* of text for a clash.

I'd approve that as an easy puzzle. Other already-commited approvers ok with that?
I'm ok with that.

I read MasakiKyosuke's latest comment as an ok too, so I'm going forward.

I'll make a toplevel comment about the editing.
I agreed for sure ! :)
